var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Cmstar Downloader: Lurid and Enfal's New Cousin","name":"Cmstar Downloader: Lurid and Enfal's New Cousin","description":"In recent weeks, Unit 42 has been analyzing delivery documents used in spear-phishing attacks that drop a custom downloader used in cyber espionage attacks. This specific downloader, Cmstar, is associated with the Lurid downloader also known as \u2018Enfal\u2019. Cmstar was named for the log message \u2018CM**\u2019 used by the downloader. Unit 42 is aware of","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin\/","datePublished":"May 18, 2015","articleBody":"In recent weeks, Unit 42 has been analyzing delivery documents used in spear-phishing attacks that drop a custom downloader used in cyber espionage attacks. This specific downloader, Cmstar, is associated with the Lurid downloader also known as \u2018Enfal\u2019. Cmstar was named for the log message \u2018CM**\u2019 used by the downloader.\n\nUnit 42 is aware of threat actors using two toolkits - MNKit and the Tran Duy Linh toolkit - to produce malicious documents that exploit CVE-2012-0158 in order to implant Cmstar. The Cmstar downloader itself has several unique and interesting features, as well as substantial infrastructure overlap with other tools worth discussing.\nManual Building of Import Address Table\nThe Cmstar downloader starts by manually building its import address table (IAT), much like shellcode would; however, it uses a rather unique technique. Instead of finding API function names based on their hashed values, this malware enumerates libraries' export address table (EAT) and searches for the name of the API function the payload needs to load by using a character to offset array. The payload pairs several comma-separated lists of characters with comma-separated lists of numbers. Each list of characters consists of the set found within the API function name the payload seeks to add to its IAT, while the corresponding list of numbers specifies the offset in the function name where those characters should be placed. For example, if the payload has \"D,e,A\" paired with \"0,5,19\", this results in the following mapping:\n\n\t\"D\" at offset 0 in API function name\n\t\"e\" at offset 5 in API function name\n\t\"A\" at offset 19 in API function name\n\nThe payload loads a specific Windows library's EAT by calling the ImageDirectoryEntryToData API function using the IMAGE_DIRECTORY_ENTRY_EXPORT flag. It then enumerates the library's EAT to find exported function names by checking each function name for the character and the specific offset. Once found, the payload adds the address for the specific API function to its IAT. For instance, the payload checks the EAT of \"wininet.dll\" using the comparisons mentioned above to find the address to the \"DeleteUrlCacheEntryA\" API function. One specific Cmstar payload that we analyzed used the character\/offsets seen in Figure 1 to locate the API functions within three different Windows libraries to build its IAT.\n\n\n\nLibrary\nCharacters\nOffsets\nFunction Name\n\n\nwininet.dll\nD,e,A\n0,5,19\nDeleteUrlCacheEntryA\n\n\ne,O,A\n3,8,12\nInternetOpenA\n\n\ne,C,A\n3,8,15\nInternetConnectA\n\n\np,O,A\n3,4,15\nHttpOpenRequestA\n\n\np,S,A\n3,4,15\nHttpSendRequestA\n\n\np,E,A\n3,4,14\nHttpEndRequestA\n\n\np,Q,A\n3,4,13\nHttpQueryInfoA\n\n\ne,R,e\n3,8,15\nInternetReadFile\n\n\ne,C,e\n3,8,18\nInternetCloseHandle\n\n\nadvapi32.dll\nS,V,A\n3,6,13\nRegSetValueExA\n\n\nC,s,y\n3,6,10\nRegCloseKey\n\n\nO,K,A\n3,7,12\nRegOpenKeyExA\n\n\nD,K,A\n3,9,12\nRegDeleteKeyA\n\n\nD,V,A\n3,9,14\nRegDeleteValueA\n\n\nU,r,A\n3,6,11\nGetUserNameA\n\n\nv,t,S\n3,6,12\nConvertSidToStringSidA\n\n\nk,A,A\n3,6,17\nLookupAccountNameA\n\n\nkernel32.dll\nW,E,c\n0,3,6\nWinExec\n\n\nC,M,A\n0,10,17\nCreateFileMappingA\n\n\nU,V,e\n0,5,14\nUnmapViewOfFile\n\n\nM,O,e\n0,7,12\nMapViewOfFile\n\n\n\nFigure 1.\u00a0Character and Offset Pairs Found in Cmstar Payload and the Resulting API Function Names\nCmstar Behavior\nAfter manually creating the IAT, Cmstar decrypts its configuration, several encrypted strings, and a piece of shellcode. The embedded configuration contains nothing more than a URL that Cmstar uses as its command and control (C2) location. The encrypted strings within the Trojan include fields used within the HTTP requests that Cmstar will create to communicate with its C2 server, as well as additional strings used to interact with the registry. The Cmstar sample associated with the MNKIT delivery document creates the following registry key to automatically execute at system startup:\n\n\tHKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run\\xpsfiltsvcs: \"rundll32.exe\n\tC:\\DOCUME~1\\ADMINI~1\\LOCALS~1\\Temp\\xpsfiltsvcs.dll,XpsRegisterServer\"\n\nUnit 42 found an additional encrypted registry key that would allow Cmstar to automatically start up after reboots. However, the code does not decrypt, reference, or use the following registry key in any way, which suggests that the malware author left this artifact in the code after swapping to the run key listed above:\n\n\tHKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\CTF\\LangBarAddIn\n\nCmstar also decrypts a 752-byte piece of shellcode that carries out communications with the C2 server, specifically by sending HTTP POST requests to the following URL:\n\n\thttp:\/\/happy.launchtrue[.]com:8080\/cgl-bin\/update.cgi\n\nIt should be noted that the C2 URL contains the string \u2018cgl-bin\u2019, which visually resembles the common cgi-bin folder used by many webservers to run server-side scripts. Unit 42 used the Palo Alto Networks AutoFocus threat intelligence service to locate additional samples using the \u2018cgl-bin\u2019 string within URLs of HTTP requests and found several samples of the Cmwhite tool associated with the LURID\/Enfal downloader1, as seen in Figure 2.\n\n\n\n&nbsp;\nFigure 2.\u00a0Cmwhite Tools Using \"cgl-bin\" within HTTP Requests\nCmstar\u2019s HTTP POST requests sent to \u2018happy.launchtrue[.]com\u2019 contain data that the Trojan gathers from the infected machine that has the following structure:\n\n&lt;Windows Version number&gt;@@&lt;CPU Architecture (2 for x64, 1 for x86)&gt;??&lt;boolean for elevated privileges&gt;]]**&lt;boolean if antivirus processes are found&gt;!!&lt;static version string&gt;==\n\nIn one example, Unit 42 observed the following data within an analysis environment, which was then encrypted using a single-byte XOR algorithm and a key of 0x45 before being sent to the C2 server:\n\n510@@1??1]]**0!!150316o==\n\nHelpfully, the malware author writes log messages to the \u2018DF64159.TMP\u2019 file, used for debugging purposes throughout the execution of the Cmstar downloader. The log messages are abbreviated strings that describe specific activities during the execution of the code. For instance, the downloader uses the CreateMutex to create a mutex named \u2018{53A4988C-F91F-4054-9076-220AC5EC03F3}\u2019 to determine if another instance of the code is running. If the downloader determines another instance of itself is running, the code writes the string \u2018CM**\u2019 - which happens to be the basis for the name of the Trojan - to the log file. Unit 42 created a Yara signature to detect Cmstar samples based on these debugging strings, which is available in the appendix.\nHashing Process Names\nAs mentioned in the behavioral analysis section, the Cmstar downloader gathers system-specific information to send to the C2 server. One such piece of information is the existence of specific running processes. Many malware families and tools check for the existence of antivirus, but the Cmstar tool does so in a clever way. Rather than including a list of strings of associated processes, Cmstar enumerates the running processes and subjects these process names to a hashing algorithm. The results of this algorithm are then compared against three static values: 0x1E00AFA, 0xBEE091E8 and 0xD46FCDFA. Unit 42 reverse engineered the algorithm and created the function seen below to generate hashes in order to determine the processes Cmstar is trying to find:\ndef hashStr(st):\n\n\u00a0\u00a0 hash = 0\n\n\u00a0\u00a0 count = 0\n\n\u00a0\u00a0 while count &lt; len(st):\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 h1 = (hash&lt;&lt;0x13)&amp;0xFFFFFFFF\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 h2 = (hash&gt;&gt;0x0d)&amp;0xFFFFFFFF\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 h3 = (h1|h2)&amp;0xFFFFFFFF\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 hash = (h3 + (ord(st[count])^0x4a))&amp;0xFFFFFFFF\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 count += 1\n\n\u00a0\u00a0 return hash\n\n\u00a0\n\nUnit 42 found that the string \u2018avp\u2019 subjected to the algorithm above results in the value 0x1E00AFA, which suggests the Cmstar sample specifically looks for Kaspersky's Anti-virus product (avp.exe) running on the compromised system. If the Trojan finds processes whose hash matches the three values mentioned earlier, it sets a boolean value (the character \u20181\u2019) within the data sent to the C2 server and continues carrying out its functionality. Rather than altering its activities, Cmstar only notifies the C2 server if a system is running one of these processes, suggesting that the threat actors might employ this technique as a filtering mechanism to ignore analysis systems and researchers.\nThreat Infrastructure\nIn order to determine the intrusion set involved with the Cmstar, Unit 42 enumerated infrastructure used by the downloader for its C2 servers. The related infrastructure chart in Figure 3 shows a rather large cluster of related entities with one small set of entities that do not share any related entities with the larger cluster.\n\n\nFigure 3.\u00a0Infrastructure and Entites Related to Cmstar\nAs seen in the chart above, the C2 domain \u2018happy.launchtrue[.]com\u2019 was originally registered using the email address \u2018WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM\u2019. When Unit 42 used the Palo Alto Networks AutoFocus threat intelligence service to locate additional Cmstar samples, we found several with C2 domains that also had the same original registrant:\n\n\tlinks.dogsforhelp[.]com\n\tthree.earewq[.]com\n\tquestion.eboregi[.]com\n\there.pechooin[.]com\n\tsarey.phdreport[.]com\n\tbakler.featurvoice[.]com\n\nThe only known Cmstar C2 domain not initially registered by the email address was help.ubxpi0s[.]com. Further analysis revealed that additional domains related to Cmstar C2 domains were also originally registered using the email address \u2018WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM\u2019 and updated to the current information within a few days. In addition, this was the original registrant for C2 domain used in our Google Code blog2, indicating this registrant email is likely a re-seller, and\/or someone who initially sets up infrastructure for particular APT threat actors.\n\n\tforever.cowforhelp[.]com\n\tquestion.shiesiido[.]com\n\tendline.biortherm[.]com\n\tright.marubir[.]com\n\tbaby.brabbq[.]com\n\tlind.kruptcy[.]com\n\nThe rest of the domains related to the Cmstar infrastructure did not use the original registrant noted above, but instead kept the same information initially used to register them. The difference in domain registration patterns could indicate threat actor preference, or could indicate there are at least two groups using this malware whose infrastructure at times overlaps.\n\n\tunder.suttgte[.]com\n\thelp.ubxpi0s[.]com\n\tfinally.basiccompare[.]com\n\tcrystal.diskfunc[.]com\n\tqueenfansclub[.]com\n\tnovnitie[.]com\n\tflash-vip[.]com\n\treplyfunt[.]com\n\tnatcongress[.]com\n\tkeep.regebky[.]com\n\tlove.regebky[.]com\n\nInterestingly, the updated registrant information (or original, in the cases where it wasn\u2019t changed) for all of the C2 domains in this blog has also been used to register scam sites, most purporting to sell knock-off designer products like shoes, software, or cell phones.\u00a0 The contact emails and contact names can vary, but the address is re-used. Blue Coat noted this pattern as well in a blog published late last year, which also noted the\u00a0 \u2018WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM\u2019 registrant email.3 It is not known whether the threat actors conducting the malicious activity are also behind the scam sites.\n\u00a0Conclusion\nThe Cmstar tool has several interesting features, including a previously unseen method of manually creating its import address table using an API function name character to offset mapping techniques, and a hashing algorithm used to find antivirus processes on an infected system. Both of these features are noteworthy and may provide the ability to correlate future tools to the same group and\/or malware authors.\n\nThe URL used by Cmstar to communicate with its C2 server, as well as significant infrastructure overlap, show a direct relationship between the Cmstar downloader, Lurid\/Enfal and Cmwhite tools. In a majority of the cases, threat actors using the Cmstar downloader initially register the C2 domains using the email address \u2018WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM\u2019 and later change the registration information to include a different email address. Unit 42 cannot positively confirm that the threat actors control the \u2018WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM\u2019 email address, or if the email address belongs to a reseller that the threat actors buy domains from to create their infrastructure; however, we do believe this is an interesting TTP worth tracking in future infrastructure enumeration.\n\n\tTHE \u201cLURID\u201dDOWNLOADER - Nart Villeneuve and David Sancho - http:\/\/la.trendmicro.com\/media\/misc\/lurid-downloader-enfal-report-en.pdf\n\tAttacks on East Asia using Google Code for Command and Control \u2013 Jen Miller-Osborn and Rob Downs -- http:\/\/blog.paloaltonetworks.com\/2014\/08\/attacks-east-asia-using-google-code-command-control\/\n\tLinking APTs from 2011 and 2014 to an Active Scam Network \u2013 Kiel Wadner -\u00a0https:\/\/www.bluecoat.com\/security-blog\/2014-10-08\/linking-apts-2011-and-2014-active-scam-network\n\n\u00a0Appendix\nKnown Cmstar Downloaders\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: 239a25ac2b38f0be9392ceeaeab0d64cb239f033af07ed56565ba9d6a7ddcf1f\nC2: links.dogsforhelp.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: 6b557c22ab12e8ea43d29e4f9f8a9483e3e75cd41338a674c9069b6dacdf7ba7\nC2: question.eboregi.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: 7ade616a8f1750cecba944a02e2bce1340b18a55697b29f721ccc4701aadba6e\nC2: links.dogsforhelp.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: 88184983733f4d4fa767ad4e7993b01c5754f868470dd78ac1bad2b02c9e5001\nC2: here.pechooin.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: b9d597aea53023727d8564e47e903b652f5e98a2c32bdc23bc4936448fb2d593\nC2: question.eboregi.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: e0b3cc07d3a9b509480b240368dee2a29713ea1e240674c0ccf610c84810a7c5\nC2: question.eboregi.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.txt\nSHA256: f4b8f71c0e10a345a855763e01033e2144e949c8f98c271755cc025e3f55b7da\nC2: three.earewq.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: 2e00a98212c5a2015d12612f0d26039a0c2dfee3e1b384675f613e683f276e02\nC2: bakler.featurvoice.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.dll\nSHA256: 42ed2edc37b957266ff7b02955a007dd82d955c09ef7be23e685d938e40ad61d\nC2: turber.xoxcobbs.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.dll\nSHA256: 9b9cc7e2a2481b0472721e6b87f1eba4faf2d419d1e2c115a91ab7e7e6fc7f7c\nC2: happy.launchtrue.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: a330c52b7643de9d8be51a4ae0150b7b8390dbabaea9704069694835fbd3298e\nC2: three.earewq.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: a8fa487d9f2152738bf49c8c69e8a147aae55c06f37c7e25026a28f21601ad7f\nC2: sarey.phdreport.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: c99c0b37f2fd64fa523d39c35ead6416a684ae203ae728feb5feff8490eb902c\nC2: help.ubxpi0s.com\n\nFilename: xpsfiltsvcs.tmp\nSHA256: d541280b37dd5e2101cc5cd47b0991b8320714f5627b37646330136cddef0c23\nC2: three.earewq.com\n\nFilename: coyote_load.dll\nSHA256: adb05c1eecd789582886b3354b53831df9c9a06e891bb687633ee7ce21417edc\nC2: bakler.featurvoice.com\nDelivery Documents Installing Cmstar\nFilename: \u041a\u0430\u043a\u0430\u044f \u0440\u0435\u0444\u043e\u0440\u043c\u0430 \u0430\u0440\u043c\u0438\u0438 \u043d\u0443\u0436\u043d\u0430 \u0423\u043a\u0440\u0430\u0438\u043d\u0435.doc (What is needed reform of the army Ukraine.doc)\nMD5: 76ffb9c2d8d0ae46e8ea792ffacc8018\nSHA256: c26c67eac20614038aaadfda19b604862926433333893d65332928b5e36796aa\nType: MIME entity text\nToolkit: MNKit\nAuthor:     <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x

</script>

<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">
    
<section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/article-banner.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
			              <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" role="link" title="Malware" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:breadcrumb:Malware">Malware</a></li> </ul>
            </div>            <div class="ab__title">
              <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:Malware"><span class="ab-title__pre">Malware</span></a> 
              <h1>Cmstar Downloader: Lurid and Enfal's New Cousin</h1>
              <div class="ab__video">
              <span class="duration"> 
                <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-clock.svg" alt="Clock Icon"><span class="span-reading-time rt-reading-time"><span class="rt-label rt-prefix"></span> <span class="rt-time"> 9</span> <span class="rt-label rt-postfix"></span></span> min read              </span>
                              </div>          
              <div class="ab-lc__wrapper">
                              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="ab__footer">
            <div class="l-container">
              <div class="ab__footer-wrapper">
                <ul class="ab__features" role="list">
                  <li role="listitem">
				 <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-profile-grey.svg" alt="Profile Icon">
					 <div class="ab__text"><span>By:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:Robert Falcone" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/robertfalcone/">Robert Falcone</a></li></ul></div></li>                  <li role="listitem">
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-calendar-grey.svg" alt="Published Icon">
			<div class="ab__text"><span>Published:</span>May 18, 2015</div></li>					<li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-category.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Categories:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:Malware" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/">Malware</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:Threat Research" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/">Threat Research</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                  <li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-tags-grey.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Tags:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:cmstar" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/cmstar/">Cmstar</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:enfal" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/enfal/">Enfal</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:lurid" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/lurid/">Lurid</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:hero:Spear Phishing" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/spear-phishing/">Spear Phishing</a></li></ul></div>

                <div class="ab__options">

	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p>In recent weeks, Unit 42 has been analyzing delivery documents used in spear-phishing attacks that drop a custom downloader used in cyber espionage attacks. This specific downloader, Cmstar, is associated with the Lurid downloader also known as ‘Enfal’. Cmstar was named for the log message ‘CM**’ used by the downloader.</p>
<p>Unit 42 is aware of threat actors using two toolkits - MNKit and the Tran Duy Linh toolkit - to produce malicious documents that exploit CVE-2012-0158 in order to implant Cmstar. The Cmstar downloader itself has several unique and interesting features, as well as substantial infrastructure overlap with other tools worth discussing.<span id="more-9131"></span></p>
<h3>Manual Building of Import Address Table</h3>
<p>The Cmstar downloader starts by manually building its import address table (IAT), much like shellcode would; however, it uses a rather unique technique. Instead of finding API function names based on their hashed values, this malware enumerates libraries' export address table (EAT) and searches for the name of the API function the payload needs to load by using a character to offset array. The payload pairs several comma-separated lists of characters with comma-separated lists of numbers. Each list of characters consists of the set found within the API function name the payload seeks to add to its IAT, while the corresponding list of numbers specifies the offset in the function name where those characters should be placed. For example, if the payload has "D,e,A" paired with "0,5,19", this results in the following mapping:</p>
<ul>
<li>"D" at offset 0 in API function name</li>
<li>"e" at offset 5 in API function name</li>
<li>"A" at offset 19 in API function name</li>
</ul>
<p>The payload loads a specific Windows library's EAT by calling the ImageDirectoryEntryToData API function using the IMAGE_DIRECTORY_ENTRY_EXPORT flag. It then enumerates the library's EAT to find exported function names by checking each function name for the character and the specific offset. Once found, the payload adds the address for the specific API function to its IAT. For instance, the payload checks the EAT of "wininet.dll" using the comparisons mentioned above to find the address to the "DeleteUrlCacheEntryA" API function. One specific Cmstar payload that we analyzed used the character/offsets seen in Figure 1 to locate the API functions within three different Windows libraries to build its IAT.</p>
<table>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="82"><strong>Library</strong></td>
<td width="79"><strong>Characters</strong></td>
<td width="57"><strong>Offsets</strong></td>
<td width="135"><strong>Function Name</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="9" width="82">wininet.dll</td>
<td width="79">D,e,A</td>
<td width="57">0,5,19</td>
<td width="135">DeleteUrlCacheEntryA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">e,O,A</td>
<td width="57">3,8,12</td>
<td width="135">InternetOpenA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">e,C,A</td>
<td width="57">3,8,15</td>
<td width="135">InternetConnectA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">p,O,A</td>
<td width="57">3,4,15</td>
<td width="135">HttpOpenRequestA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">p,S,A</td>
<td width="57">3,4,15</td>
<td width="135">HttpSendRequestA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">p,E,A</td>
<td width="57">3,4,14</td>
<td width="135">HttpEndRequestA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">p,Q,A</td>
<td width="57">3,4,13</td>
<td width="135">HttpQueryInfoA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">e,R,e</td>
<td width="57">3,8,15</td>
<td width="135">InternetReadFile</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">e,C,e</td>
<td width="57">3,8,18</td>
<td width="135">InternetCloseHandle</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="8" width="82">advapi32.dll</td>
<td width="79">S,V,A</td>
<td width="57">3,6,13</td>
<td width="135">RegSetValueExA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">C,s,y</td>
<td width="57">3,6,10</td>
<td width="135">RegCloseKey</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">O,K,A</td>
<td width="57">3,7,12</td>
<td width="135">RegOpenKeyExA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">D,K,A</td>
<td width="57">3,9,12</td>
<td width="135">RegDeleteKeyA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">D,V,A</td>
<td width="57">3,9,14</td>
<td width="135">RegDeleteValueA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">U,r,A</td>
<td width="57">3,6,11</td>
<td width="135">GetUserNameA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">v,t,S</td>
<td width="57">3,6,12</td>
<td width="135">ConvertSidToStringSidA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">k,A,A</td>
<td width="57">3,6,17</td>
<td width="135">LookupAccountNameA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="4" width="82">kernel32.dll</td>
<td width="79">W,E,c</td>
<td width="57">0,3,6</td>
<td width="135">WinExec</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">C,M,A</td>
<td width="57">0,10,17</td>
<td width="135">CreateFileMappingA</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">U,V,e</td>
<td width="57">0,5,14</td>
<td width="135">UnmapViewOfFile</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="79">M,O,e</td>
<td width="57">0,7,12</td>
<td width="135">MapViewOfFile</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><strong>Figure 1</strong>. Character and Offset Pairs Found in Cmstar Payload and the Resulting API Function Names</p>
<h3>Cmstar Behavior</h3>
<p>After manually creating the IAT, Cmstar decrypts its configuration, several encrypted strings, and a piece of shellcode. The embedded configuration contains nothing more than a URL that Cmstar uses as its command and control (C2) location. The encrypted strings within the Trojan include fields used within the HTTP requests that Cmstar will create to communicate with its C2 server, as well as additional strings used to interact with the registry. The Cmstar sample associated with the MNKIT delivery document creates the following registry key to automatically execute at system startup:</p>
<ul>
<li>HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\xpsfiltsvcs: "rundll32.exe</li>
<li>C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\xpsfiltsvcs.dll,XpsRegisterServer"</li>
</ul>
<p>Unit 42 found an additional encrypted registry key that would allow Cmstar to automatically start up after reboots. However, the code does not decrypt, reference, or use the following registry key in any way, which suggests that the malware author left this artifact in the code after swapping to the run key listed above:</p>
<ul>
<li>HKCU\Software\Microsoft\CTF\LangBarAddIn</li>
</ul>
<p>Cmstar also decrypts a 752-byte piece of shellcode that carries out communications with the C2 server, specifically by sending HTTP POST requests to the following URL:</p>
<ul>
<li>http://happy.launchtrue[.]com:8080/cgl-bin/update.cgi</li>
</ul>
<p>It should be noted that the C2 URL contains the string ‘cgl-bin’, which visually resembles the common cgi-bin folder used by many webservers to run server-side scripts. Unit 42 used the Palo Alto Networks AutoFocus threat intelligence service to locate additional samples using the ‘cgl-bin’ string within URLs of HTTP requests and found several samples of the Cmwhite tool associated with the LURID/Enfal downloader<sup>1</sup>, as seen in Figure 2.</p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Cmstar1.png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img  class="aligncenter wp-image-9135 size-large lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Cmstar1-500x411.png" alt="Cmstar1" width="500" height="411" /></a></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Figure 2</strong>. Cmwhite Tools Using "cgl-bin" within HTTP Requests</p>
<p>Cmstar’s HTTP POST requests sent to ‘happy.launchtrue[.]com’ contain data that the Trojan gathers from the infected machine that has the following structure:</p>
<p><em>&lt;Windows Version number&gt;@@&lt;CPU Architecture (2 for x64, 1 for x86)&gt;??&lt;boolean for elevated privileges&gt;]]**&lt;boolean if antivirus processes are found&gt;!!&lt;static version string&gt;==</em></p>
<p>In one example, Unit 42 observed the following data within an analysis environment, which was then encrypted using a single-byte XOR algorithm and a key of 0x45 before being sent to the C2 server:</p>
<p><em>510@@1??1]]**0!!150316o==</em></p>
<p>Helpfully, the malware author writes log messages to the ‘DF64159.TMP’ file, used for debugging purposes throughout the execution of the Cmstar downloader. The log messages are abbreviated strings that describe specific activities during the execution of the code. For instance, the downloader uses the CreateMutex to create a mutex named ‘{53A4988C-F91F-4054-9076-220AC5EC03F3}’ to determine if another instance of the code is running. If the downloader determines another instance of itself is running, the code writes the string ‘CM**’ - which happens to be the basis for the name of the Trojan - to the log file. Unit 42 created a Yara signature to detect Cmstar samples based on these debugging strings, which is available in the appendix.</p>
<h3>Hashing Process Names</h3>
<p>As mentioned in the behavioral analysis section, the Cmstar downloader gathers system-specific information to send to the C2 server. One such piece of information is the existence of specific running processes. Many malware families and tools check for the existence of antivirus, but the Cmstar tool does so in a clever way. Rather than including a list of strings of associated processes, Cmstar enumerates the running processes and subjects these process names to a hashing algorithm. The results of this algorithm are then compared against three static values: 0x1E00AFA, 0xBEE091E8 and 0xD46FCDFA. Unit 42 reverse engineered the algorithm and created the function seen below to generate hashes in order to determine the processes Cmstar is trying to find:</p><!-- Crayon Syntax Highlighter v_2.7.2_beta -->

		<div id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552" class="crayon-syntax crayon-theme-classic crayon-font-monaco crayon-os-pc print-yes notranslate" data-settings=" minimize scroll-mouseover wrap" style=" margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
		
			<div class="crayon-toolbar" data-settings=" mouseover overlay hide delay" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><span class="crayon-title"></span>
			<div class="crayon-tools" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><div class="crayon-button crayon-nums-button" title="Toggle Line Numbers"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-plain-button" title="Toggle Plain Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-wrap-button" title="Toggle Line Wrap"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-expand-button" title="Expand Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-copy-button" title="Copy"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-popup-button" title="Open Code In New Window"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div></div></div>
			<div class="crayon-info" style="min-height: 16.8px !important; line-height: 16.8px !important;"></div>
			<div class="crayon-plain-wrap"><textarea  class="crayon-plain print-no" data-settings="dblclick" readonly style="-moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
def hashStr(st):

   hash = 0

   count = 0

   while count &lt; len(st):

       h1 = (hash&lt;&lt;0x13)&amp;0xFFFFFFFF

       h2 = (hash&gt;&gt;0x0d)&amp;0xFFFFFFFF

       h3 = (h1|h2)&amp;0xFFFFFFFF

       hash = (h3 + (ord(st[count])^0x4a))&amp;0xFFFFFFFF

       count += 1

   return hash

 </textarea></div>
			<div class="crayon-main" style="">
				<table class="crayon-table">
					<tr class="crayon-row">
				<td class="crayon-nums " data-settings="show">
					<div class="crayon-nums-content" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;"><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-1">1</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-2">2</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-3">3</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-4">4</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-5">5</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-6">6</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-7">7</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-8">8</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-9">9</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-10">10</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-11">11</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-12">12</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-13">13</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-14">14</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-15">15</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-16">16</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-17">17</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-18">18</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-19">19</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-20">20</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-21">21</div></div>
				</td>
						<td class="crayon-code"><div class="crayon-pre" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important; -moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4;"><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-1"><span class="crayon-e">def </span><span class="crayon-e">hashStr</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">st</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-2">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-3">  <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">hash</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-cn">0</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-4">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-5">  <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">count</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-cn">0</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-6">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-7">  <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-st">while</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">count</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-h">&lt;</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">len</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">st</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-8">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-9">      <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">h1</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">hash</span><span class="crayon-h">&lt;</span><span class="crayon-h">&lt;</span><span class="crayon-cn">0x13</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-h">&amp;0xFFFFFFFF</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-10">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-11">      <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">h2</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">hash</span><span class="crayon-h">&gt;</span><span class="crayon-h">&gt;</span><span class="crayon-cn">0x0d</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-h">&amp;0xFFFFFFFF</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-12">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-13">      <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">h3</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">h1</span><span class="crayon-sy">|</span><span class="crayon-i">h2</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-h">&amp;0xFFFFFFFF</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-14">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-15">      <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">hash</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">h3</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>+<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-e">ord</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-i">st</span><span class="crayon-sy">[</span><span class="crayon-i">count</span><span class="crayon-sy">]</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span>^<span class="crayon-cn">0x4a</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-h">&amp;0xFFFFFFFF</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-16">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-17">      <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">count</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>+=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-cn">1</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-18">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-19">  <span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-st">return</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">hash</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-20">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39f0816143552-21"> </div></div></td>
					</tr>
				</table>
			</div>
		</div>
<!-- [Format Time: 0.0002 seconds] -->
<p>Unit 42 found that the string ‘avp’ subjected to the algorithm above results in the value 0x1E00AFA, which suggests the Cmstar sample specifically looks for Kaspersky's Anti-virus product (avp.exe) running on the compromised system. If the Trojan finds processes whose hash matches the three values mentioned earlier, it sets a boolean value (the character ‘1’) within the data sent to the C2 server and continues carrying out its functionality. Rather than altering its activities, Cmstar only notifies the C2 server if a system is running one of these processes, suggesting that the threat actors might employ this technique as a filtering mechanism to ignore analysis systems and researchers.</p>
<h3>Threat Infrastructure</h3>
<p>In order to determine the intrusion set involved with the Cmstar, Unit 42 enumerated infrastructure used by the downloader for its C2 servers. The related infrastructure chart in Figure 3 shows a rather large cluster of related entities with one small set of entities that do not share any related entities with the larger cluster.</p>
<p><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Cmstar2.png" rel="wpdevart_lightbox"><img  class="aligncenter size-large wp-image-9136 lozad"  data-src="http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Cmstar2-500x451.png" alt="Cmstar2" width="500" height="451" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Figure 3</strong>. Infrastructure and Entites Related to Cmstar</p>
<p>As seen in the chart above, the C2 domain ‘happy.launchtrue[.]com’ was originally registered using the email address ‘WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM’. When Unit 42 used the Palo Alto Networks AutoFocus threat intelligence service to locate additional Cmstar samples, we found several with C2 domains that also had the same original registrant:</p>
<ul>
<li>links.dogsforhelp[.]com</li>
<li>three.earewq[.]com</li>
<li>question.eboregi[.]com</li>
<li>here.pechooin[.]com</li>
<li>sarey.phdreport[.]com</li>
<li>bakler.featurvoice[.]com</li>
</ul>
<p>The only known Cmstar C2 domain not initially registered by the email address was help.ubxpi0s[.]com. Further analysis revealed that additional domains related to Cmstar C2 domains were also originally registered using the email address ‘WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM’ and updated to the current information within a few days. In addition, this was the original registrant for C2 domain used in our Google Code blog<sup>2</sup>, indicating this registrant email is likely a re-seller, and/or someone who initially sets up infrastructure for particular APT threat actors.</p>
<ul>
<li>forever.cowforhelp[.]com</li>
<li>question.shiesiido[.]com</li>
<li>endline.biortherm[.]com</li>
<li>right.marubir[.]com</li>
<li>baby.brabbq[.]com</li>
<li>lind.kruptcy[.]com</li>
</ul>
<p>The rest of the domains related to the Cmstar infrastructure did not use the original registrant noted above, but instead kept the same information initially used to register them. The difference in domain registration patterns could indicate threat actor preference, or could indicate there are at least two groups using this malware whose infrastructure at times overlaps.</p>
<ul>
<li>under.suttgte[.]com</li>
<li>help.ubxpi0s[.]com</li>
<li>finally.basiccompare[.]com</li>
<li>crystal.diskfunc[.]com</li>
<li>queenfansclub[.]com</li>
<li>novnitie[.]com</li>
<li>flash-vip[.]com</li>
<li>replyfunt[.]com</li>
<li>natcongress[.]com</li>
<li>keep.regebky[.]com</li>
<li>love.regebky[.]com</li>
</ul>
<p>Interestingly, the updated registrant information (or original, in the cases where it wasn’t changed) for all of the C2 domains in this blog has also been used to register scam sites, most purporting to sell knock-off designer products like shoes, software, or cell phones.  The contact emails and contact names can vary, but the address is re-used. Blue Coat noted this pattern as well in a blog published late last year, which also noted the  ‘WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM’ registrant email.<sup>3 </sup>It is not known whether the threat actors conducting the malicious activity are also behind the scam sites.</p>
<h3> Conclusion</h3>
<p>The Cmstar tool has several interesting features, including a previously unseen method of manually creating its import address table using an API function name character to offset mapping techniques, and a hashing algorithm used to find antivirus processes on an infected system. Both of these features are noteworthy and may provide the ability to correlate future tools to the same group and/or malware authors.</p>
<p>The URL used by Cmstar to communicate with its C2 server, as well as significant infrastructure overlap, show a direct relationship between the Cmstar downloader, Lurid/Enfal and Cmwhite tools. In a majority of the cases, threat actors using the Cmstar downloader initially register the C2 domains using the email address ‘WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM’ and later change the registration information to include a different email address. Unit 42 cannot positively confirm that the threat actors control the ‘WANGMINGHUA6@GMAIL[.]COM’ email address, or if the email address belongs to a reseller that the threat actors buy domains from to create their infrastructure; however, we do believe this is an interesting TTP worth tracking in future infrastructure enumeration.</p>
<ol>
<li>THE “LURID”DOWNLOADER - Nart Villeneuve and David Sancho - <a href="https://la.trendmicro.com/media/misc/lurid-downloader-enfal-report-en.pdf" target="_blank">http://la.trendmicro.com/media/misc/lurid-downloader-enfal-report-en.pdf</a></li>
<li><a href="https://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2014/08/attacks-east-asia-using-google-code-command-control/">Attacks on East Asia using Google Code for Command and Control</a> – Jen Miller-Osborn and Rob Downs -- http://blog.paloaltonetworks.com/2014/08/attacks-east-asia-using-google-code-command-control/</li>
<li>Linking APTs from 2011 and 2014 to an Active Scam Network – Kiel Wadner - <a href="https://www.bluecoat.com/security-blog/2014-10-08/linking-apts-2011-and-2014-active-scam-network">https://www.bluecoat.com/security-blog/2014-10-08/linking-apts-2011-and-2014-active-scam-network</a></li>
</ol>

<h4>Cmstar Yara Rule</h4>
<p></p><!-- Crayon Syntax Highlighter v_2.7.2_beta -->

		<div id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323" class="crayon-syntax crayon-theme-classic crayon-font-monaco crayon-os-pc print-yes notranslate" data-settings=" minimize scroll-mouseover wrap" style=" margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
		
			<div class="crayon-toolbar" data-settings=" mouseover overlay hide delay" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><span class="crayon-title"></span>
			<div class="crayon-tools" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><div class="crayon-button crayon-nums-button" title="Toggle Line Numbers"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-plain-button" title="Toggle Plain Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-wrap-button" title="Toggle Line Wrap"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-expand-button" title="Expand Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-copy-button" title="Copy"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-popup-button" title="Open Code In New Window"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div></div></div>
			<div class="crayon-info" style="min-height: 16.8px !important; line-height: 16.8px !important;"></div>
			<div class="crayon-plain-wrap"><textarea  class="crayon-plain print-no" data-settings="dblclick" readonly style="-moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
rule ce_enfal_cmstar_debug_msg

{

meta:

author = "rfalcone"

description = "Detects the static debug strings within CMSTAR"

reference = "9b9cc7e2a2481b0472721e6b87f1eba4faf2d419d1e2c115a91ab7e7e6fc7f7c"

date = "5/10/2015"

strings:

$d1 = "EEE\x0d\x0a" fullword

$d2 = "TKE\x0d\x0a" fullword

$d3 = "VPE\x0d\x0a" fullword

$d4 = "VPS\x0d\x0a" fullword

$d5 = "WFSE\x0d\x0a" fullword

$d6 = "WFSS\x0d\x0a" fullword

$d7 = "CM**\x0d\x0a" fullword

condition:

uint16(0) == 0x5a4d and all of ($d*)

}</textarea></div>
			<div class="crayon-main" style="">
				<table class="crayon-table">
					<tr class="crayon-row">
				<td class="crayon-nums " data-settings="show">
					<div class="crayon-nums-content" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;"><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-1">1</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-2">2</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-3">3</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-4">4</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-5">5</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-6">6</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-7">7</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-8">8</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-9">9</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-10">10</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-11">11</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-12">12</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-13">13</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-14">14</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-15">15</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-16">16</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-17">17</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-18">18</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-19">19</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-20">20</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-21">21</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-22">22</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-23">23</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-24">24</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-25">25</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-26">26</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-27">27</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-28">28</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-29">29</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-30">30</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-31">31</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-32">32</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-33">33</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-34">34</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-35">35</div></div>
				</td>
						<td class="crayon-code"><div class="crayon-pre" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important; -moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4;"><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-1"><span class="crayon-e">rule</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">ce_enfal_cmstar_debug_msg</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-2">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-3"><span class="crayon-sy">{</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-4">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-5"><span class="crayon-i">meta</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-6">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-7"><span class="crayon-i">author</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"rfalcone"</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-8">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-9"><span class="crayon-i">description</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"Detects the static debug strings within CMSTAR"</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-10">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-11"><span class="crayon-i">reference</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"9b9cc7e2a2481b0472721e6b87f1eba4faf2d419d1e2c115a91ab7e7e6fc7f7c"</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-12">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-13"><span class="crayon-i">date</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"5/10/2015"</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-14">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-15"><span class="crayon-i">strings</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-16">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-17"><span class="crayon-sy">$</span><span class="crayon-i">d1</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"EEE\x0d\x0a"</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">fullword</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-18">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-19"><span class="crayon-sy">$</span><span class="crayon-i">d2</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"TKE\x0d\x0a"</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">fullword</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-20">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-21"><span class="crayon-sy">$</span><span class="crayon-i">d3</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"VPE\x0d\x0a"</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">fullword</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-22">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-23"><span class="crayon-sy">$</span><span class="crayon-i">d4</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"VPS\x0d\x0a"</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">fullword</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-24">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-25"><span class="crayon-sy">$</span><span class="crayon-i">d5</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"WFSE\x0d\x0a"</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">fullword</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-26">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-27"><span class="crayon-sy">$</span><span class="crayon-i">d6</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"WFSS\x0d\x0a"</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">fullword</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-28">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-29"><span class="crayon-sy">$</span><span class="crayon-i">d7</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>=<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-s">"CM**\x0d\x0a"</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">fullword</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-30">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-31"><span class="crayon-i">condition</span><span class="crayon-sy">:</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-32">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-33"><span class="crayon-e">uint16</span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-cn">0</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span>==<span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-cn">0x5a4d</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-st">and</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">all </span><span class="crayon-e">of</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-sy">(</span><span class="crayon-sy">$</span><span class="crayon-e ">d*</span><span class="crayon-sy">)</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-34">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68c4d1d4f39fa753503323-35"><span class="crayon-sy">}</span></div></div></td>
					</tr>
				</table>
			</div>
		</div>
<!-- [Format Time: 0.0002 seconds] -->
<p>&nbsp;</p>

    <div class="l-container">
            <h2>Related Malware Resources</h2>
      <div class="blog-slider" id="blogSlider"> 
                    <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/09/02_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of AdaptixC2.                             </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:related-resources:AdaptixC2: A New Open-Source Framework Leveraged in Real-World Attacks:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-09-10T10:00:15+00:00">September 10, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/adaptixc2-post-exploitation-framework/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:related-resources:AdaptixC2: A New Open-Source Framework Leveraged in Real-World Attacks">
                    <h4 class="post-title">AdaptixC2: A New Open-Source Framework Leveraged in Real-World Attacks</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/c2/" title="C2" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:related-resources:AdaptixC2: A New Open-Source Framework Leveraged in Real-World Attacks:C2">C2</a>

                    <h4 class="post-title">The Ηоmоgraph Illusion: Not Everything Is As It Seems</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/genai/" title="GenAI" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:related-resources:The Ηоmоgraph Illusion: Not Everything Is As It Seems:GenAI">GenAI</a>

                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/03-1-Muddle-Libra-1920x900-1-786x368.png" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of Muddled Libra (Scattered Spider). Illustration of a zodiac symbol Libra represented by scales, set against a cosmic purple background with stars." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/03-1-Muddle-Libra-1920x900-1-786x368.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/03-1-Muddle-Libra-1920x900-1-1493x700.png 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/03-1-Muddle-Libra-1920x900-1-768x360.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/03-1-Muddle-Libra-1920x900-1-1536x720.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/05/03-1-Muddle-Libra-1920x900-1.png 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:related-resources:Muddled Libra Threat Assessment: Further-Reaching, Faster, More Impactful:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-07-25T10:00:37+00:00">July 25, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/muddled-libra/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:related-resources:Muddled Libra Threat Assessment: Further-Reaching, Faster, More Impactful">

					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/muddled-libra/" title="Muddled Libra" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="cmstar-downloader-lurid-and-enfals-new-cousin:related-resources:Muddled Libra Threat Assessment: Further-Reaching, Faster, More Impactful:Muddled Libra">Muddled Libra</a>
